physdesc.extent: (5 boxes, 104 shoe boxes, 189 cartons, 86 flat boxes, 117 oversize flat boxes)

did.abstract: The Hollywood Turf Club, later renamed Hollywood Park, opened in 1938. Known as the Track of the Lakes and Flowers, it served as home for a number of talented jockeys, trainers, and prominent thoroughbreds. The collection consists of minute books and ledgers; stock certificate books; scrapbooks; negatives; press clippings; and chart books.
did.physloc: Stored off-site at SRLF. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. Please contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions on Access
accessrestrict.p: COLLECTION STORED OFF-SITE AT SRLF: Open for research. Advance notice required for access. Contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.
Box 312 is restricted and may be unavailable for use. Inquiries regarding these materials should be directed to UCLA Library Special Collections.
Many scrapbooks are in fragile condition due to clippings and/or photographs falling off pages.

userestrict.head: Conditions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical object belong to the UCLA Library Special Collections. Literary rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Hollywood Park Records (Collection 2254). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Hollywood Park Racing Association, 2014.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: The Hollywood Turf Club (later renamed Hollywood Park), opened on June 10, 1938. Constructed on close to 315 acres, it was built to accommodate 30,000 people and 1,250 horses. The race track itself was an oval one mile distance and 90 feet wide.

A year earlier, in 1937, the Los Angeles Times reported that there were two applications for a Los Angeles horse racing track: one submitted by the Golden State Jockey Club, the other from the Hollywood Racing Association. Ultimately the Golden State group was awarded a provisional permit to build. Golden State changed its name to the Hollywood Turf Club and selected a West Los Angeles location near the intersection of Sawtelle and National to build the track. Although granted a provisional permit from the California Horse Racing Board and approval from the Los Angeles Planning Commission to begin building in September 1936, there were "floods of protest" from the West Los Angeles community that led the Hollywood Turf Club to withdraw its application for zoning in West Los Angeles and select the Inglewood location that would be the home of Hollywood Park.

In January 1938, Hollywood Turf Club officers and directors included Hollywood industry figures and Los Angeles businessmen such as Walter McCarty (Beverly Wilshire Hotel), Jack Warner (Warner Bros), Earl Gilmore (Gilmore Oil Company), J. I. Schnitzer (Western Costume Company), Raoul Walsh (motion picture director), Roy Wilcox, Al Jolson (radio artist), C. M. Rood (oil operator), James Duffy (Santa Fe railroad), Thomas Simmons (oil operator), and Alfred Green (motion picture director). According to Jack Warner, the Hollywood Turf Club was to provide another outstanding attraction for visitors and tourists to Southern California.

The infield of the track was beautifully landscaped with lush gardens and small lakes. The Hollywood Park Goose Girl tradition began during the park's first season in 1938. Each year a Goose Girl was chosen and in addition to posing for photographs and making publicity appearances, she would walk among the geese (and other birds) that populated the infield or coast along on the lake in the small boat, the Miz Clementine, feeding the birds. The tradition was discontinued in the 1970s and brought back for a very brief time in the 1990s. In May 1949, less than two weeks before the opening of the track's spring racing season, a fire severely damaged the original grand stand and Club House. The track reopened a little more than a year later in June 1950. Known as the Track of the Lakes and Flowers, Hollywood Park served as home for a number of talented horsemen and eminent thoroughbreds. Among the horses were Seabiscuit, winner of the inaugural Hollywood Gold Cup in 1938, three-time Gold Cup champions Native Diver and Lava Man, Triple Crown winners Citation, Seattle Slew and Affirmed, Great Communicator, Landaluce, and Zenyatta. Jockeys Eddie Arcaro, Jerry Bailey, Jerry Lambert, Donny Longden, Laffit Pincay, Jr., Bill Shoemaker, Mike Smith, Gary Stevens, and George Woolf; and trainers Charlie Whittingham, Barrera Lax, Bob Baffert, and Doug O'Neill also worked at the park. Three legendary horses, Landaluce, Native Diver, and Great Communicator were interned at the race park.
Hollywood Park closed December 22, 2013, ending 75 years of continuous racing in the Southern California region. It was demolished to make way for a residential development.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of material related to Hollywood Park and the California racing community. Included are minute books and ledgers; stock certificate books; scrapbooks; negatives; press clippings; and chart books. The minute books and ledgers represent annual and special meetings of the Hollywood Turf Club and Hollywood Park. The stock certificate books comprise stock certificate sales for the first decade of the track's operation. The scrapbooks and press clippings document media coverage of Hollywood Park, as well as other racetracks such as Santa Anita, Los Alamitos, and the California horse racing culture. The negatives represent Hollywood Park racing seasons and track events. The chart books provide racing statistics regarding horses, jockeys, and odds mostly for the other regional race tracks, with only one chart book representing Hollywood Park.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The collection is arranged in the following series:
Series 1: Minute Books and Ledgers
Series 2: Stock Certificate Books
Series 3: Scrapbooks
Series 4: Negatives
Series 5. Press Clippings
Series 6. Chart Books

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 312 is restricted and may be unavailable for use. Inquiries regarding these materials should be directed to UCLA Library Special Collections.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: There is no specific arrangement to the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Minute Books and Ledgers consist of meeting minutes documenting annual and special meetings of the Hollywood Turf Club and Hollywood Park. The bulk of the material represents Executive Committees and Board of Directors' meetings. Additionally represented are a small number of items related to Turf Oil Company, California Turf Foundation Inc., and Prairie Wood Association Inc. In addition to meeting minutes there are a small number of documents related to ownership and incorporation. One California Turf Foundation ledger appears to be mostly doctor, hospital, and medical related entries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Appears to be records of stocks and bonds.

scopecontent.p: Portions of the contents of this scrapbook are restricted and may be unavailable for use. Inquiries regarding these materials should be directed in writing to the UCLA Library Special Collections.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The certificate books are arranged in a loose chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series comprises stock certificates representing individual purchasing of stocks, the number of shares purchased, and the date of purchase for the first decade of the track's operation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: With loose folder titled Grant, Cyrus W.; Grant, Ruth C.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The scrapbooks are arranged in a loose chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Scrapbook albums hold press clippings and/or a small amount of photographs, advertisements, and ephemera about or publicizing Hollywood Park. The press clippings include stories and photographs related to horses and jockeys, horse races, general Hollywood Park advertisements as well as press about park events, personality sightings, and information about other horse racing tracks in the California area. A portion of the scrapbooks are titled to reflect their contents. Unless otherwise noted, the scrapbooks contain press clipping only. Among the various newspapers represented are the Los Angeles Times, the Herald Examiner, the San Diego Evening Tribune, the San Diego Union, the San Francisco Chronicle and San Francisco Examiner.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The negatives are arranged in a loose chronological order with some boxes further arranged into a loose alphabetical order by event or individual's or thoroughbred's name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The negatives series comprise black and white and color negatives documenting various Hollywood Park race and track activities. The bulk of the negatives represent races, titles, and club parties with a small number of the items representing the Los Alamitos race track. Additionally, there are a very small number of printed photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: With unidentified persons and places, Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz, Jimmy Durante, Buddy Gil 'Baldwin Stakes', Early Pioneer (Hollywood Gold Cup), Gold Cup, Golden Pheasant, [Johnny] Longden, Off season: Plastic Lungs at Rancho Los Amigos, Rio Verde, Spastic Childrens Foundation, Sports Illustrated group picture, Swaps, Swaps statue at entrance of Park, Shoemaker, infield landscape, and horse races.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: With goose girl, the infield at Hollywood Park, and photographs that came loose from scrapbooks.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in a loose chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Original and photocopied press clippings, most annotated with the publication date. Included are pieces about Hollywood Park, Santa Anita, and Los Alamitos racetracks, horses and horse racing. Among the various newspapers represented are the Daily Racing Forum, the Los Angeles Times, the Herald Examiner, the Racing Times, and the Thoroughbred Times. Beginning in 1995 the files were titled by the topics of 'horse races' or 'stadiums, arenas, and casinos.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Chart Books are arranged alphabetically by race track.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Chart Book series are scrapbook-like volumes that contain clippings of race charts from what appear to be newspaper publications. Race tracks represented include the Oak Tree, Golden Gate, Santa Anita, Bay Meadows, and Los Alamitos; there is only one volume specifically representing Hollywood Park. The charts consists of statistics regarding specific horses and races, jockeys, and odds.

accessrestrict.p: Serials may be accessed, but they are currently undescribed.
